KH.content: philosophy only becomes serious in the path of logic, sublates mythology
KH.linkedContent: philosophy only becomes serious in the path of logic, sublates mythology

GOD.content: for Hegel, manifestation, unveiling, phenomenalization is given priority over secret: no final secret for philosophy, politics, ethics
GOD.linkedContent: for Hegel, manifestation, unveiling, phenomenalization is given priority over secret: no final secret for philosophy, politics, ethics

GOD.content: the speculative requires a heterotautological position (Hegel, revealed religion that is precisely Christian) [G], always risks meaning nothing, speculates on every secret [re: tout autre est tout autre]
GOD.linkedContent: the speculative requires a heterotautological position (Hegel, revealed religion that is precisely Christian) [G], always risks meaning nothing, speculates on every secret [re: tout autre est tout autre]

OOG.content: for Husserl and Hegel, culture itself in its finite empirical units is not sufficient to constitute the pure unity of a history (such is the case for all cultures that do not participate in European eidos)
OOG.linkedContent: for Husserl and Hegel, culture itself in its finite empirical units is not sufficient to constitute the pure unity of a history (such is the case for all cultures that do not participate in European eidos)

OOG.content: [like Hegel like Husserl] Logos is the pure movement of its own historicity, goes beyond “Fact” as the “ready-made” of history
OOG.linkedContent: [like Hegel like Husserl] Logos is the pure movement of its own historicity, goes beyond “Fact” as the “ready-made” of history

FK.content: [in Anidjar’s introduction] Hegel on Islam, no nationalism like Judaism [?] (lacks particularity); Islam has a universalism, Judaism doesn’t > Christianity has both
FK.linkedContent: [in Anidjar’s introduction] Hegel on Islam, no nationalism like Judaism [?] (lacks particularity); Islam has a universalism, Judaism doesn’t > Christianity has both

SPOM.content: Hegel’s end of history rung a consonant note w/ many other glas
SPOM.linkedContent: Hegel’s end of history rung a consonant note w/ many other glas

SPOM.content: Hegel’s not a philosopher of trans-historical man and nature, like Fukuyama claims
SPOM.linkedContent: Hegel’s not a philosopher of trans-historical man and nature, like Fukuyama claims

SPOM.content: Marx fights Stirner in the name of authentic betrayal of Hegel, sons fighting for authentic murder of the father, “interrupting filiation”
SPOM.linkedContent: Marx fights Stirner in the name of authentic betrayal of Hegel, sons fighting for authentic murder of the father, “interrupting filiation”

SPOM.content: acc. Marx, the ghost effect not only spiritualization, autonomization of spirit, idea, or thought (Hegelian idealism), but also supplementary moment after autonomization, one more simulacrum is added: a body, flesh (Leib)
SPOM.linkedContent: acc. Marx, the ghost effect not only spiritualization, autonomization of spirit, idea, or thought (Hegelian idealism), but also supplementary moment after autonomization, one more simulacrum is added: a body, flesh (Leib)

POOF.content: Schmitt’s Hegelian heritage, oppositional negativity is teleologically political (impossible to distinguish subject/object in speculative idealism); for Schmitt, Hegel fundamentally a political thinker, begins w/ Man as ‘evil,’ ‘dangerous’; for Schmitt, Marxism bears torch of Hegel in concrete-enemy of international class [Lukács]
POOF.linkedContent: Schmitt’s Hegelian heritage, oppositional negativity is teleologically political (impossible to distinguish subject/object in speculative idealism); for Schmitt, Hegel fundamentally a political thinker, begins w/ Man as ‘evil,’ ‘dangerous’; for Schmitt, Marxism bears torch of Hegel in concrete-enemy of international class [Lukács]

HERP.content: Heidegger’s carry the friend “bei sich (close by itself)” same expression used by Hegel for the concept remaining (bleibende) bei sich selbst in absolute knowledge
HERP.linkedContent: Heidegger’s carry the friend “bei sich (close by itself)” same expression used by Hegel for the concept remaining (bleibende) bei sich selbst in absolute knowledge

MPM.content: where Derrida’s memory differentiates from Hegel’s: no link btwn Wesen & Gewesenheit, the present doesn’t pull from a past that was present, but a trace never present
MPM.linkedContent: where Derrida’s memory differentiates from Hegel’s: no link btwn Wesen & Gewesenheit, the present doesn’t pull from a past that was present, but a trace never present

MPM.content: de Man: Hegel marginalizes sign, allegory for sake of symbol & “synthetic judgments”
MPM.linkedContent: de Man: Hegel marginalizes sign, allegory for sake of symbol & “synthetic judgments”

MPM.content: de Man quotes Hegel: allegory “disarticulation of subject from predicate” > allegory as defective cornerstone of entire system [p. 76 keystone (counts for whole) vs. cornerstone]
MPM.linkedContent: de Man quotes Hegel: allegory “disarticulation of subject from predicate” > allegory as defective cornerstone of entire system [p. 76 keystone (counts for whole) vs. cornerstone]

MPM.content: via de Man, allegory (as a metonymy) is an allegory? > Hegel’s dialectic a vast allegory not of reconciliation & synthesis but of disjunction, dissociation, and discontinuity
MPM.linkedContent: via de Man, allegory (as a metonymy) is an allegory? > Hegel’s dialectic a vast allegory not of reconciliation & synthesis but of disjunction, dissociation, and discontinuity

A.content: for Heidegger, belief in immortality is secondary to being-toward-death, an affirmation of an originary finitude Hegel thought he reversed in Kant
A.linkedContent: for Heidegger, belief in immortality is secondary to being-toward-death, an affirmation of an originary finitude Hegel thought he reversed in Kant

A.content: Heidegger’s on Kant’s side, on this side of finitude > didn’t Hegel want to show unilaterality of border, and that one is already on the other side of the here?
A.linkedContent: Heidegger’s on Kant’s side, on this side of finitude > didn’t Hegel want to show unilaterality of border, and that one is already on the other side of the here?

EM.content: phenomenology as relève of anthropology, no longer but still a science of man
EM.linkedContent: phenomenology as relève of anthropology, no longer but still a science of man

EM.content: in all structures described in Phenom… l’homme y reste en son relief, equivocal relation to relief (relevance) marque sans doute la fin de l’homme, man past, but also achievement of man > c’est la fin de l’homme fini, end of finitude of man, unity of infinite and finite
EM.linkedContent: in all structures described in Phenom… l’homme y reste en son relief, equivocal relation to relief (relevance) marque sans doute la fin de l’homme, man past, but also achievement of man > c’est la fin de l’homme fini, end of finitude of man, unity of infinite and finite

EM.content: the relevance accomplished in Hegelian metaphysics persists wherever metaphysics, our language, maintains its authority, even in pre-Hegelian systems (i.e. in Kant, figure of finitude organizes capacity to know from emergence of anthropological limit)
EM.linkedContent: the relevance accomplished in Hegelian metaphysics persists wherever metaphysics, our language, maintains its authority, even in pre-Hegelian systems (i.e. in Kant, figure of finitude organizes capacity to know from emergence of anthropological limit)

EM.content: for Hegel, Husserl, reason is history, and there is no history but of reason
EM.linkedContent: for Hegel, Husserl, reason is history, and there is no history but of reason

VM.content: Abraham exemplar of unhappy consciousness for Hegel
VM.linkedContent: Abraham exemplar of unhappy consciousness for Hegel

VM.content: Hegel would not escape the rule [see p. 91 tout-autre] > audacity to turn accusation of formalism against Hegel, denounce speculative logic of understanding as tautological [Glas]
VM.linkedContent: Hegel would not escape the rule [see p. 91 tout-autre] > audacity to turn accusation of formalism against Hegel, denounce speculative logic of understanding as tautological [Glas]

VM.content: Levinas very close to Hegel [re: relation btwn desire & eye], closer than he admits, something that happens to all anti-Hegelian thinkers [this calls for much more thought]
VM.linkedContent: Levinas very close to Hegel [re: relation btwn desire & eye], closer than he admits, something that happens to all anti-Hegelian thinkers [this calls for much more thought]

VM.content: for Hegel, hearing as ideal sense, immediate trembling of object, but also an ideal of contemplation, aesthetics [from trembling to idealism]
VM.linkedContent: for Hegel, hearing as ideal sense, immediate trembling of object, but also an ideal of contemplation, aesthetics [from trembling to idealism]

VM.content: no one thought original equivocality of language more profoundly than Hegel, accommodated duplicity & difference w/in speculation
VM.linkedContent: no one thought original equivocality of language more profoundly than Hegel, accommodated duplicity & difference w/in speculation

VM.content: only way to escape Hegel, for an instant, consider “false infinity,” original finitude, irreducible
VM.linkedContent: only way to escape Hegel, for an instant, consider “false infinity,” original finitude, irreducible

VM.content: for Levinas, if Husserlian Cogito opened to infinite, it would be an object-infinity w/out alterity, a “false infinity” [Levinas never uses this Hegelian term, but idea of indefinite, negative form of infinity haunts his gestures]; Levinas makes true alterity nonnegativity, and the same (complicit w/ negativity) the false-infinity > would have seemed absolutely mad to Hegel
VM.linkedContent: for Levinas, if Husserlian Cogito opened to infinite, it would be an object-infinity w/out alterity, a “false infinity” [Levinas never uses this Hegelian term, but idea of indefinite, negative form of infinity haunts his gestures]; Levinas makes true alterity nonnegativity, and the same (complicit w/ negativity) the false-infinity > would have seemed absolutely mad to Hegel

VM.content: in this language, our only language, how can we not repeat Hegelianism > this language coming into absolute possession of itself?
VM.linkedContent: in this language, our only language, how can we not repeat Hegelianism > this language coming into absolute possession of itself?

VM.content: to speak against Hegel is to confirm him [re: Levinas]
VM.linkedContent: to speak against Hegel is to confirm him [re: Levinas]

VM.content: for Hegel (against Levinas), difference btwn same and other has no meaning in infinite, except to speak of anxiety of infinite which determines & negates itself > violence in horizon of infinite is that where differance is no longer valid, where peace would no longer have meaning
VM.linkedContent: for Hegel (against Levinas), difference btwn same and other has no meaning in infinite, except to speak of anxiety of infinite which determines & negates itself > violence in horizon of infinite is that where differance is no longer valid, where peace would no longer have meaning

VM.content: Hegel recognized negativity, anxiety or war in infinite absolute, as movement of absolute’s own history, whose horizon is a final pacification in which alterity would be absolutely encapsulated (résumée), if not lifted up (levée), in parousia
VM.linkedContent: Hegel recognized negativity, anxiety or war in infinite absolute, as movement of absolute’s own history, whose horizon is a final pacification in which alterity would be absolutely encapsulated (résumée), if not lifted up (levée), in parousia

VM.content: Heidegger allows Hegel’s discourse to grow and speak (Hegel’s discourse as that of all metaphysics)
VM.linkedContent: Heidegger allows Hegel’s discourse to grow and speak (Hegel’s discourse as that of all metaphysics)

VM.content: “alterity, difference, and time are not suppressed but retained by absolute knowledge in the form of the Aufhebung”
VM.linkedContent: “alterity, difference, and time are not suppressed but retained by absolute knowledge in the form of the Aufhebung”

VM.content: Hegel’s speculative logic: living logic which reconciles formal tautology and empirical heterology [after having thought prophetic discourse in preface to Phenom…]
VM.linkedContent: Hegel’s speculative logic: living logic which reconciles formal tautology and empirical heterology [after having thought prophetic discourse in preface to Phenom…]

VM.content: for Hegel, absolute difference (which he thought) can only be pure difference by being impure
VM.linkedContent: for Hegel, absolute difference (which he thought) can only be pure difference by being impure

VP.content: Hegel seems more radical than Husserl in that he demands thought of positive infinite, so that “the indefiniteness of differance may appear as such”
VP.linkedContent: Hegel seems more radical than Husserl in that he demands thought of positive infinite, so that “the indefiniteness of differance may appear as such”

VP.content: Hegel’s criticism of Kant would hold for Husserl; but since ideal, infinite differance only appears in relation to my-death, appearing of infinite differance is finite, the infinite differance is finite
VP.linkedContent: Hegel’s criticism of Kant would hold for Husserl; but since ideal, infinite differance only appears in relation to my-death, appearing of infinite differance is finite, the infinite differance is finite

S.content: Heidegger: Hegel’s concept of time is “the most radical elaboration of the vulgar concept of time”; in vulgar concept of time, spirit falls into time determined as negation of negation, spirit presents itself as negation of negation too, its essence is the concept
S.linkedContent: Heidegger: Hegel’s concept of time is “the most radical elaboration of the vulgar concept of time”; in vulgar concept of time, spirit falls into time determined as negation of negation, spirit presents itself as negation of negation too, its essence is the concept

S.content: acc. Heidegger, Hegelian spirit ruled by epoch of Cartesian cogito, thus calls for deconstruction; Hegel called Descartes the Christopher Columbus of philosophical modernity
S.linkedContent: acc. Heidegger, Hegelian spirit ruled by epoch of Cartesian cogito, thus calls for deconstruction; Hegel called Descartes the Christopher Columbus of philosophical modernity

PPHS.content: Hegel’s Encyplopedia (don’t substantialize each moment, it’s a living movement): —Logic: Idea in and for itself —Nature: Idea in its otherness —Spirit: Idea comes back to itself
PPHS.linkedContent: Hegel’s Encyplopedia (don’t substantialize each moment, it’s a living movement): —Logic: Idea in and for itself —Nature: Idea in its otherness —Spirit: Idea comes back to itself

PPHS.content: [Hegel describes St. Anselm like from Bounty to Illumination]
PPHS.linkedContent: [Hegel describes St. Anselm like from Bounty to Illumination]

PPHS.content: acc. Hegel, poetry, most relevant art (time & sound), must be spoken, not read (united to conceptual representation unlike music)
PPHS.linkedContent: acc. Hegel, poetry, most relevant art (time & sound), must be spoken, not read (united to conceptual representation unlike music)

PPHS.content: Hegel: “we think in names” [magic?] ex: “lion” [Hegel contradicts privilege of sign?]
PPHS.linkedContent: Hegel: “we think in names” [magic?] ex: “lion” [Hegel contradicts privilege of sign?]

PPHS.content: irreducible privilege accorded to the name in Hegel: name as simple, not decomposed, plain idea (simple sign of exact idea)
PPHS.linkedContent: irreducible privilege accorded to the name in Hegel: name as simple, not decomposed, plain idea (simple sign of exact idea)

PPHS.content: acc. Hegel, thanks to name we can do w/out image & sensory existence [hieroglyph]
PPHS.linkedContent: acc. Hegel, thanks to name we can do w/out image & sensory existence [hieroglyph]

PPHS.content: Hegel: human voice sounds w/out external impulse, out of one’s own feelings, spirit
PPHS.linkedContent: Hegel: human voice sounds w/out external impulse, out of one’s own feelings, spirit

PPHS.content: Hegel against Leibniz, mathematics, Pythagoras, all perversions of philosophical model, must “pass through” spacing, exteriority & death (negativity) (see “Preface” of Pheno…) [not remain]
PPHS.linkedContent: Hegel against Leibniz, mathematics, Pythagoras, all perversions of philosophical model, must “pass through” spacing, exteriority & death (negativity) (see “Preface” of Pheno…) [not remain]

PPHS.content: for Hegel, machine works as a negation w/out relève, thus Hegel could never think a machine that could work! that which doesn’t work in service of meaning: pure loss
PPHS.linkedContent: for Hegel, machine works as a negation w/out relève, thus Hegel could never think a machine that could work! that which doesn’t work in service of meaning: pure loss

PPHS.content: but Derrida sees machine working by itself, outside > Hegel’s logic, syntax, concepts, engaged in system of this unpower [of course, not enough to “essentialize” technology]
PPHS.linkedContent: but Derrida sees machine working by itself, outside > Hegel’s logic, syntax, concepts, engaged in system of this unpower [of course, not enough to “essentialize” technology]

PPHS.content: [Hegel on calculation and machine] a “living,” “thinking,” “speaking” protest against repetition
PPHS.linkedContent: [Hegel on calculation and machine] a “living,” “thinking,” “speaking” protest against repetition

FSW.content: Hegel, Plato, Proust perhaps, believe past present can be awakened in its truth
FSW.linkedContent: Hegel, Plato, Proust perhaps, believe past present can be awakened in its truth

T.content: Hegel: to attain philosophy, necessary [for body] to cast itself into abyss à corps perdu
T.linkedContent: Hegel: to attain philosophy, necessary [for body] to cast itself into abyss à corps perdu

T.content: Hegel’s triangulocircular structure (spiral wheel); from Vitruvius’ wedge to Hegelian spiral [Vitruvius’ tympanum to Lafaye’s tympanum]
T.linkedContent: Hegel’s triangulocircular structure (spiral wheel); from Vitruvius’ wedge to Hegelian spiral [Vitruvius’ tympanum to Lafaye’s tympanum]

OS.content: Hegel taught us: results are nothing w/out becoming, w/out itinerary or method
OS.linkedContent: Hegel taught us: results are nothing w/out becoming, w/out itinerary or method

OS.content: Heidegger often considered Hegel to have covered over Kant’s audaciousness, though…
OS.linkedContent: Heidegger often considered Hegel to have covered over Kant’s audaciousness, though…

OS.content: Hegel: Notion is in and for itself absolute (total) negativity and freedom
OS.linkedContent: Hegel: Notion is in and for itself absolute (total) negativity and freedom

POS.content: we will never be done (re)reading Hegel, all I do is explain this point, Hegel’s text is fissured, not reduced to its philosophemes, its circular closure of representation, leaves a remainder of writing (Feuerbach posed question of Hegel the writer, insufficiently)
POS.linkedContent: we will never be done (re)reading Hegel, all I do is explain this point, Hegel’s text is fissured, not reduced to its philosophemes, its circular closure of representation, leaves a remainder of writing (Feuerbach posed question of Hegel the writer, insufficiently)

SP.content: Hegel on passivity of clittoral pleasure (de la jouissance clitoridienne)
SP.linkedContent: Hegel on passivity of clittoral pleasure (de la jouissance clitoridienne)

FS.content: translation of Hegel not finished (thank the Lord!): thus explaining Proust, Joyce, Faulkner > Flaubert feared Hegel, rightfully so; Mallarmé, uniquely, approached Hegel: [why he (alone) knew he couldn’t complete the book?]
FS.linkedContent: translation of Hegel not finished (thank the Lord!): thus explaining Proust, Joyce, Faulkner > Flaubert feared Hegel, rightfully so; Mallarmé, uniquely, approached Hegel: [why he (alone) knew he couldn’t complete the book?]

FS.content: Proust’s aesthetic/critical method not outside the work, but heart of its creation > the end of the book engenders its beginning (Derrida compares Proust to Hegel)

O.content: lesson of Hegel’s to be maintained even beyond Hegelianism: complicity of empiricism/formalism
O.linkedContent: lesson of Hegel’s to be maintained even beyond Hegelianism: complicity of empiricism/formalism

O.content: for Hegel, exteriority of negative still belongs to process of truth—must leave its trace upon it
O.linkedContent: for Hegel, exteriority of negative still belongs to process of truth—must leave its trace upon it

O.content: Hegel on having to publish System of Science separately from Phenomenology: “necessary expansion which logic demanded”
O.linkedContent: Hegel on having to publish System of Science separately from Phenomenology: “necessary expansion which logic demanded”

O.content: Hegel tells us that Plato edited Republic 7 times, so modern philosopher (dealing w/ richer material) should edit 77 times
O.linkedContent: Hegel tells us that Plato edited Republic 7 times, so modern philosopher (dealing w/ richer material) should edit 77 times

O.content: Hegel allows for insistence [TN. (in + sistere) “standing firm in”] of a gap btwn form/content, btwn what he calls certainty and truth
O.linkedContent: Hegel allows for insistence [TN. (in + sistere) “standing firm in”] of a gap btwn form/content, btwn what he calls certainty and truth

O.content: Derrida explains many traps Hegel tries to avoid, i.e. rejecting formalism in name of inspiration (Begeisterung)
O.linkedContent: Derrida explains many traps Hegel tries to avoid, i.e. rejecting formalism in name of inspiration (Begeisterung)

O.content: Shelling’s triplicity of death vs. Hegel’s living triplicity of concept
O.linkedContent: Shelling’s triplicity of death vs. Hegel’s living triplicity of concept

O.content: Hegel: spirit is a trinity, but cannot be counted (counting is a bad procedure)
O.linkedContent: Hegel: spirit is a trinity, but cannot be counted (counting is a bad procedure)

O.content: le détour d’une écriture dont one ne revient pas, dissemination: this question calls for restaging of arithmos, “counting” as “bad procedure,” and rereading the rhythmos of Democritus, which philosophy has never been able to reckon w/ (n’aura pu compter) > philosophy accounts for itself by rising out of, and then circulating w/in its speculative necessity, the [envelope of writing]
O.linkedContent: le détour d’une écriture dont one ne revient pas, dissemination: this question calls for restaging of arithmos, “counting” as “bad procedure,” and rereading the rhythmos of Democritus, which philosophy has never been able to reckon w/ (n’aura pu compter) > philosophy accounts for itself by rising out of, and then circulating w/in its speculative necessity, the [envelope of writing]

O.content: scriptural apparatus of Hegel’s opening w/ sense-certainty
O.linkedContent: scriptural apparatus of Hegel’s opening w/ sense-certainty

O.content: acc. Feuerbach, Hegel’s exposition was supposed to have presupposed nothing, to leave no residue, empty & drain us completely
O.linkedContent: acc. Feuerbach, Hegel’s exposition was supposed to have presupposed nothing, to leave no residue, empty & drain us completely

O.content: Feuerbach on Hegel as a “game-player”: to Hegel the thinker, formally, absolute idea was an absolute certainty, to Hegel the writer, idea is a formal uncertainty
O.linkedContent: Feuerbach on Hegel as a “game-player”: to Hegel the thinker, formally, absolute idea was an absolute certainty, to Hegel the writer, idea is a formal uncertainty

O.content: Hegel’s philosophical encyclopedia, last of its kind in history to deserve the name > encyclopedia is thoroughly theological in essence/origin (despite the so-called atheistic one)
O.linkedContent: Hegel’s philosophical encyclopedia, last of its kind in history to deserve the name > encyclopedia is thoroughly theological in essence/origin (despite the so-called atheistic one)

O.content: re: writing, Hegel does not think exteriority, repetitive autonomy of remainder > writing becomes pro-gramme, pre-scription, pre-text, the simple empirical husk (déchet) of concept
O.linkedContent: re: writing, Hegel does not think exteriority, repetitive autonomy of remainder > writing becomes pro-gramme, pre-scription, pre-text, the simple empirical husk (déchet) of concept

O.content: for Derrida, this husk is coextensive w/ whole life of discourse
O.linkedContent: for Derrida, this husk is coextensive w/ whole life of discourse

DIF.content: Hegel’s difference: verschieden, ungleich > differance as radical, infinitesimal displacement of Hegelian discourse (while maintaining profound affinity)
DIF.linkedContent: Hegel’s difference: verschieden, ungleich > differance as radical, infinitesimal displacement of Hegelian discourse (while maintaining profound affinity)

RGE.content: misconstrued, treated lightly, Hegelianism expands its historical domination w/ its immense enveloping resources
RGE.linkedContent: misconstrued, treated lightly, Hegelianism expands its historical domination w/ its immense enveloping resources

RGE.content: Bataille: no one knows anything of himself if he has not grasped Hegel’s master/slave dialectic
RGE.linkedContent: Bataille: no one knows anything of himself if he has not grasped Hegel’s master/slave dialectic

RGE.content: there’s only one discourse, it is significative, no getting around Hegel here
RGE.linkedContent: there’s only one discourse, it is significative, no getting around Hegel here

RGE.content: difference btwn Bataille/Hegel (btwn 2 differences): Bataille evokes absolute difference that’s not in service of presence > continuum, communication, instant (concepts of Batailles’ sovereign operation) not identical [MOP] but mark/sharpen incision of difference
RGE.linkedContent: difference btwn Bataille/Hegel (btwn 2 differences): Bataille evokes absolute difference that’s not in service of presence > continuum, communication, instant (concepts of Batailles’ sovereign operation) not identical [MOP] but mark/sharpen incision of difference

RGE.content: Bataille: Hegel’s failure not an error, an authentic movement, pregnant w/ meaning
RGE.linkedContent: Bataille: Hegel’s failure not an error, an authentic movement, pregnant w/ meaning

RGE.content: Bataille: Hegel’s memory takes him back to perceived abyss in order to annihilate it, the system is annihilation (Hegel touched the extreme, he knew supplication)
RGE.linkedContent: Bataille: Hegel’s memory takes him back to perceived abyss in order to annihilate it, the system is annihilation (Hegel touched the extreme, he knew supplication)

RGE.content: Bataille took Hegel seriously: understood internal rigor of system—couldn’t pull one part out
RGE.linkedContent: Bataille took Hegel seriously: understood internal rigor of system—couldn’t pull one part out

RGE.content: rigorous effect of trembling to which Bataille submits Hegel’s concepts
RGE.linkedContent: rigorous effect of trembling to which Bataille submits Hegel’s concepts

RGE.content: Bataille quotes Hegel’s “life of mind…endures death and in death maintains its being”  [Blanchot quotes this too, see DPi pp. 111-12]
RGE.linkedContent: Bataille quotes Hegel’s “life of mind…endures death and in death maintains its being” [Blanchot quotes this too, see DPi pp. 111-12]

RGE.content: Hegel’s master/slave cannot be summarized w/out being mistreated
RGE.linkedContent: Hegel’s master/slave cannot be summarized w/out being mistreated

RGE.content: acc. Bataille, blind spot in Hegel: une dépense, a radical negativity, sans réserve, sovereign operation, point of nonreserve
RGE.linkedContent: acc. Bataille, blind spot in Hegel: une dépense, a radical negativity, sans réserve, sovereign operation, point of nonreserve

RGE.content: Hegel’s precipitation toward seriousness of meaning (security of knowledge) blinded him to absolute expenditure laid bare under rubric of negativity > which is why he was right, and wrong for being so, for triumphing over the negative
RGE.linkedContent: Hegel’s precipitation toward seriousness of meaning (security of knowledge) blinded him to absolute expenditure laid bare under rubric of negativity > which is why he was right, and wrong for being so, for triumphing over the negative

RGE.content: since Hegel’s [all] logic is an interpretation, is submitted to an interpretive decision, it can be interpreted against him > reinterpretation: simulated repetition of Hegelian discourse
RGE.linkedContent: since Hegel’s [all] logic is an interpretation, is submitted to an interpretive decision, it can be interpreted against him > reinterpretation: simulated repetition of Hegelian discourse

RGE.content: minute displacement disjoints articulations, trembling spreads out—old shell cracks
RGE.linkedContent: minute displacement disjoints articulations, trembling spreads out—old shell cracks

RGE.content: by interpreting negativity as labor, by betting for discourse/meaning/history, Hegel bet against play, chance, blinded himself to what made his own bet possible > each stage through spirit (each suspension of play) was a phase of play: play includes work of meaning (meaning of work) not in terms of knowledge but in terms of inscription: meaning inscribed in meaningless play
RGE.linkedContent: by interpreting negativity as labor, by betting for discourse/meaning/history, Hegel bet against play, chance, blinded himself to what made his own bet possible > each stage through spirit (each suspension of play) was a phase of play: play includes work of meaning (meaning of work) not in terms of knowledge but in terms of inscription: meaning inscribed in meaningless play

TN.content: Hegel on German, the good luck of a language originally speculative [i.e. Aufhebung, denken and danken]
TN.linkedContent: Hegel on German, the good luck of a language originally speculative [i.e. Aufhebung, denken and danken]

E.content: Hegel critiques Kant’s 3rd Critique for staying at the level of “you must” > he very well evinces the moral order that sustains the aesthetic one
E.linkedContent: Hegel critiques Kant’s 3rd Critique for staying at the level of “you must” > he very well evinces the moral order that sustains the aesthetic one

OG.content: Hegel already caught up in passage beyond himself, in deconstruction, by summing up philosophy of logos, assigning to presence the eschatology of parousia, describing self-proximity of infinite subjectivity
OG.linkedContent: Hegel already caught up in passage beyond himself, in deconstruction, by summing up philosophy of logos, assigning to presence the eschatology of parousia, describing self-proximity of infinite subjectivity

OG.content: though [eschatological] Hegel reappropriates trace in absolute knowledge, he is also the thinker of irreducible difference, last writer of book, first of writing > reintroduced necessity of written trace in philosophy, rehabilitated thought as the memory productive of signs
OG.linkedContent: though [eschatological] Hegel reappropriates trace in absolute knowledge, he is also the thinker of irreducible difference, last writer of book, first of writing > reintroduced necessity of written trace in philosophy, rehabilitated thought as the memory productive of signs

OG.content: Descartes drove out sign, Hegel reappropriates sensible sign to movement of Idea, but only Rousseau dealt directly w/ reduction of writing
OG.linkedContent: Descartes drove out sign, Hegel reappropriates sensible sign to movement of Idea, but only Rousseau dealt directly w/ reduction of writing

OG.content: Leibniz’s pasigraphy, non-European scripts, inspired a breach which Rousseau sought to fill w/ the voice > a battle is declared, “Hegelianism” en sera la plus belle cicatrice
OG.linkedContent: Leibniz’s pasigraphy, non-European scripts, inspired a breach which Rousseau sought to fill w/ the voice > a battle is declared, “Hegelianism” en sera la plus belle cicatrice

OG.content: ontotheology of logos (par excellence w/ Hegel): powerless, oneiric effort to master absence by reducing the metaphor w/in absolute parousia of sense/meaning (sens)
OG.linkedContent: ontotheology of logos (par excellence w/ Hegel): powerless, oneiric effort to master absence by reducing the metaphor w/in absolute parousia of sense/meaning (sens)

EU.content: philosophy finds itself inscribed w/in space it can’t order, opens to an other not even its other > in a tympanum as little Hegelian as possible
EU.linkedContent: philosophy finds itself inscribed w/in space it can’t order, opens to an other not even its other > in a tympanum as little Hegelian as possible

SPEC.content: Freud’s speculation does not construct itself by itself like Hegel’s: however concerned w/ revenants, ne revient pas sur lui-même
SPEC.linkedContent: Freud’s speculation does not construct itself by itself like Hegel’s: however concerned w/ revenants, ne revient pas sur lui-même

SPEC.content: [re: fort/da]: selbstgeschaffene (self-invented) game, spontaneity, auto-production, self-engendering of repetition itself, hetero-tautology (definition of Hegelian speculative): gives time, there is time
SPEC.linkedContent: [re: fort/da]: selbstgeschaffene (self-invented) game, spontaneity, auto-production, self-engendering of repetition itself, hetero-tautology (definition of Hegelian speculative): gives time, there is time

SPEC.content: no relève of PP—not Hegelian [since PP always master?] > in fact, function of PP, (postal) binding, determines interpretation of Aufhebung
